ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You will learn to think critically about very challenging questions with no easy answers, including how to conceptualize sexual autonomy, the limitations of consent, and so many other fascinating and profoundly relevant questions

This course introduced me to contemporary debates and issues about sexual consent. I learned SO much about the limitations of consent, feminist theory, and how race/gender/class interact with sex and sexual violence.

I learned SO much, more than I can possibly quantify, about both the legal and theoretical landscape around sexual consent in the United States and how both have changed over time. Specifically, learned about how sexuality, gender identity, disability, and other categories can impact the meaning and experiences of sexual consent for different groups. Much of what I learned impacted my personal thinking and politics. I think my writing also improved in this course thanks to great feedback from the professor and TF!

I feel I gained an incredible amount from this course. I view many instances related to gender, sexuality, ability, and consent with far more nuance than before. I am incredibly grateful to have taken this course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Amazing course! Really encourages critical thinking skills and changes/challenges your opinions.

The material each week is deeply fascinating, challenging, and rewarding to grapple with. Prof. Fischel is an amazing, insanely knowledgeable, and understanding instructor who is incredible at facilitating great class discussions and encouraging the conversations to reach deeper levels. His style of conducting seminars is excellent, and he creates an environment in which students can feel comfortable participating (which is not always the case in classes that deal with difficult, challenging topics). Genuinely cannot think of any weaknesses for this course.

There was a wide variety of incredible readings that made me consider the issue of consent from many new perspectives. I liked how the syllabus included Yale's sexual misconduct policies, and the course material always felt extremely relevant and urgent. I also appreciated the inclusion of podcasts, TV show episodes, and articles, in addition to more traditional academic works. For the most part, the guest speakers were amazing, and I thought Professor Fischel was a gracious and thoughtful leader of discussions.

I looked forward to this course every week because our discussions were so engaging, and every single piece of material was absolutely fascinating. There was a good deal of reading and writing, but it was all WORTH IT. My favorite course of the semester! If anything, there was so much amazing material to cover that the discussions sometimes felt a bit rushed, but again, worth it because I learned so much!
This course was incredibly interesting and engaging, and the largest strength rested in the discussions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It felt like there was little understanding, both in the syllabus and from the professor, about the difficulty of the pandemic. There was no break, extensions were unlikely, and the workload felt uncompromisingly heavy. Several of the readings could have and should have been cut.

Prof. Fischel managed a seminar during COVID better than any other professor I have seen. Just to name a few of the ways in which the class excelled in responding to this format: encouraging student participation through the hand-raise function, briefly sharing slides to recap but not using Powerpoint throughout the whole class, having a brief break in the middle of class, and understanding that students might need to have their camera off at brief intervals. I would be much more excited about virtual semesters if all professors were both as adept and understanding as Prof. Fischel in adapting their teaching practices to the unique environment of the pandemic.

Professor Fischel split the class into two groups and had one group responsible for making discussion posts each week. Whichever group was "on" that week was also expected to be prepared to answer any questions Professor Fischel asked, which gave the "off" group a bit of a breather.

I think this course worked great in a virtual setting! It moved at a quick pace, so it was easy to stay engaged, and our conversations and guest speakers were amazing. Our homework included readings, podcasts, videos, and more, and this variety of types of media was much more engaging than if we had only been assigned readings.
Seminar discussions are particularly difficult over Zoom, but this class engaged with it better than any other I've experienced.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes 100% take it if you have the chance

YES!! Without a doubt! Every single Yale student should take this course. It is rare to find courses at Yale that are so thought-provoking, intellectually stimulating, impactful on one's worldview and life, and to top it all of taught by such a brilliant and kind instructor. Everyone can get something very meaningful out of this class, whether or not you are a WGSS major or have prior academic or advocacy background in the topics of this course.

Yes!!!! Consent is SO relevant to us as college students, and interrogating the ways we think about consent is crucial before we graduate. The readings in this class are also just fascinating, and we all have a stake in this conversation.
100%!! No matter how little or much you have thought through the complexities of sexual consent, I guarantee that you will learn something new from this course.
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had a few guest speakers, but the format was still mainly a moderated discussion.
Virtual seminar discussions.
